text: <extra_id_0> p105 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p98 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> precursor proteins play an active role in NF-kappa B - mediated signal transduction .

The Rel / NF-kappa B family of transcription factors is composed of two distinct subgroups , proteins that undergo proteolytic processing and contain SWI6 / ankyrin repeats in their carboxyl termini ( <extra_id_0> p105 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> p98 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , and those without such repeats that do not require processing ( <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> RelB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> Dorsal <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .

We demonstrate that the <extra_id_0> p105 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p98 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> precursors share functional properties with the I kappa B proteins , which also contain SWI6 / ankyrin repeats .

Both <extra_id_0> p105 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p98 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were found to form stable complexes with other Rel / NF-kappa B family members , including <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Association with the precursors is sufficient for cytoplasmic retention of either <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , both of which are otherwise nuclear .

These complexes undergo stimulus - responsive processing to produce active <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p55 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> c-Rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> complexes .
These observations suggest a second pathway leading to NF-kappa B induction , in which processing of the precursors rather than phosphorylation of I kappa B plays a major role .
